items.title: How Trumpâ€™s policies are affecting early-career scientistsâ€”in their own words
items.summary: Every year MIT Technology Review celebrates accomplished young scientists, entrepreneurs, and inventors from around the world in our Innovators Under 35 list. Weâ€™ve just published the 2025 edition. This year, though, the context is pointedly different: The US scientific community finds itself in anâ€¦
items.body: Every year MIT Technology Review celebrates accomplished young scientists, entrepreneurs, and inventors from around the world in our Innovators Under 35 list . Weâ€™ve just published the 2025 edition . This year, though, the context is pointedly different: The US scientific community finds itself in an unprecedented position, with the very foundation of its work under attack .  Since Donald Trump took office in January, his administration has fired top government scientists , targeted universities individually and academia more broadly , and made substantial funding cuts to the countryâ€™s science and technology infrastructure . It has also upended longstanding rights and norms related to free speech, civil rights, and immigrationâ€”all of which further affects the overall environment for research and innovation in science and technology.  We wanted to understand how these changes are affecting the careers and work of our most recent classes of innovators. The US government is the largest source of research funding at US colleges and universities, and many of our honorees are new professors and current or recent graduate or PhD students, while others work with government-fundeâ€¦

items.title: 2025 Innovator of the Year: Sneha Goenka for developing an ultra-fast sequencing technology
items.summary: Sneha Goenka is one of MIT Technology Reviewâ€™s 2025 Innovators Under 35. Meet the rest of this yearâ€™s honorees. Up to a quarter of children entering intensive care have undiagnosed genetic conditions. To be treated properly, they must first get diagnosesâ€”which means having their genomes sequenced. â€¦
items.body: Sneha Goenka is one of MIT Technology Reviewâ€™s 2025 Innovators Under 35.  Meet the rest of this yearâ€™s honorees .   Up to a quarter of children entering intensive care have undiagnosed genetic conditions. To be treated properly, they must first get diagnosesâ€”which means having their genomes sequenced. This process typically takes up to seven weeks. Sadly, thatâ€™s often too slow to save a critically ill child. Hospitals may soon have a faster option, thanks to a groundbreaking system built in part by Sneha Goenka , an assistant professor of electrical and computer engineering at Princetonâ€”and MIT Technology Review â€™s 2025 Innovator of the Year.  Five years ago, Goenka and her colleagues designed a rapid-sequencing pipeline that can provide a genetic diagnosis in less than eight hours. Goenkaâ€™s software computations and hardware architectures were critical to speeding up each stage of the process.  â€œHer work made everyone realize that genome sequencing is not only for research and medical application in the future but can have immediate impact on patient care,â€ says Jeroen de Ridder , a professor at UMC Utrecht in the Netherlands, who has developed an ultrafast seâ€¦

items.title: Meet the Ethiopian entrepreneur who is reinventing ammonia production
items.summary: Iwnetim Abate is one of MIT Technology Reviewâ€™s 2025 Innovators Under 35. Meet the rest of this yearâ€™s honorees. â€œIâ€™m the only one who wears glasses and has eye problems in the family,â€ Iwnetim Abate says with a smile as sun streams in through the windows of his MIT office. â€œI think itâ€™s because ofâ€¦
items.body: Iwnetim Abate is one of MIT Technology Reviewâ€™s 2025 Innovators Under 35.  Meet the rest of this yearâ€™s honorees .   â€œIâ€™m the only one who wears glasses and has eye problems in the family,â€ Iwnetim Abate says with a smile as sun streams in through the windows of his MIT office. â€œI think itâ€™s because of the candles.â€ In the small town in Ethiopia where he grew up, Abateâ€™s family had electricity, but it was unreliable. So, for several days each week when they were without power, Abate would finish his homework by candlelight. Today, Abate, 32, is an assistant professor at MIT in the department of materials science and engineering. Part of his research focuses on sodium-ion batteries, which could be cheaper than the lithium-based ones that typically power electric vehicles and grid installations. Heâ€™s also pursuing a new research path, examining how to harness the heat and pressure under the Earthâ€™s surface to make ammonia, a chemical used in fertilizer and as a green fuel. Growing up without the ubiquitous access to electricity that many people take for granted shaped the way Abate thinks about energy issues, he says. He recalls rushing to dry out his school uniform over aâ€¦

items.title: How Yichao â€œPeakâ€ Ji became a global AI app hitmaker
items.summary: Yichao â€œPeakâ€ Ji is one of MIT Technology Reviewâ€™s 2025 Innovators Under 35. Meet the rest of this yearâ€™s honorees. When Yichao Jiâ€”also known as â€œPeakâ€â€”appeared in a launch video for Manus in March, he didnâ€™t expect it to go viral. Speaking in fluent English, the 32-year-old introduced the AI agentâ€¦
items.body: Yichao â€œPeakâ€ Ji is one of MIT Technology Reviewâ€™s 2025 Innovators Under 35. Meet the rest of this yearâ€™s honorees . When Yichao Jiâ€”also known as â€œPeakâ€â€”appeared in a launch video for Manus in March, he didnâ€™t expect it to go viral. Speaking in fluent English, the 32-year-old introduced the AI agent built by Chinese startup Butterfly Effect, where he serves as chief scientist. The video was not an elaborate productionâ€”it was directed by cofounder Zhang Tao and filmed in a corner of their Beijing office. But something about Jiâ€™s delivery, and the vision behind the product, cut through the noise. The product, then still an early preview available only through invite codes, spread across the Chinese internet to the world in a matter of days. Within a week of its debut, Manus had attracted a waiting list of around 2 million people.  At first sight, Manus works like most chatbots: Users can ask it questions in a chat window. However, besides providing answers, it can also carry out tasks (for example, finding an apartment that meets specified criteria within a certain budget). It does this by breaking tasks down into steps, then using a cloud-based virtual machine equipped with a â€¦

items.title: I Hate My AI Friend
items.summary: The chatbot-enabled Friend necklace eavesdrops on your life and provides a running commentary thatâ€™s snarky and unhelpful. Worse, it can also make the people around you uneasy.

items.title: Bose QuietComfort Ultra Earbuds (2nd Gen): Excellent Buds
items.summary: With slight, useful changes like wireless charging and better processing, these noise-canceling buds remain at the top of the pile.

items.title: Wade to leave Wigan for union return at Newcastle
items.summary: Christian Wade will leave Wigan Warriors at the end of the rugby league season in order to return to rugby union with Newcastle Red Bulls from December.

items.title: Spurs 'not for sale' as owner rejects buyout interest
items.summary: Board says club's owner has "unequivocally rejected" two expressions of interest in buying it.

items.title: Alcaraz overcomes Sinner to win US Open
items.summary: Carlos Alcaraz triumphs in the latest chapter of his compelling rivalry with Jannik Sinner, earning a four-set victory to regain the US Open title.

items.title: 'Take back little Molly' - McCann takes pay cut to box
items.summary: Molly McCann wants to be world champion in boxing within eight fights and eyes a match at Goodison Park.

items.title: Why does the universe exist?
items.summary: The universe exists because matter and antimatter are not good friends.

items.title: Iturrioz denies Hull at Houston Championship
items.summary: England's Charley Hull finishes joint second as Spain's Nuria Iturrioz wins the Houston Championship by two shots.

items.title: Nagelsmann's Northern Ireland comments disrespectful - Craigan
items.summary: BBC Sport NI pundit Stephen Craigan feels comments from Germany coach Julian Nagelsmann on Northern Ireland were "disrespectful".

items.title: Were Nagelsmann's NI comments 'disrespectful' or 'deflective'?
items.summary: BBC Sport NI pundit Stephen Craigan feels comments from Germany coach Julian Nagelsmann on Northern Ireland were "disrespectful".

items.title: 'Don't be afraid' - how 'faultless' Alcaraz beat Sinner
items.summary: Before the US Open, Carlos Alcaraz told himself to "go for it, don't be afraid". He lived by that motto as he went on to take the title.

items.title: Ten standout moments from World Cup pool stage
items.summary: Here are 10 standout moments from the pool stage of the Women's Rugby World Cup - some of which went viral.

items.title: 'I see you more than my family' - Alcaraz on Sinner rivalry
items.summary: Carlos Alcaraz joked that he sees Jannik Sinner more than his family - but it is difficult to see who can challenge them.

items.title: USA thump GB&I to win Walker Cup
items.summary: Great Britain and Ireland collapse to a 17-9 defeat by the USA in the Walker Cup in California.

items.title: Alcaraz edges Sinner trilogy to win US Open
items.summary: Carlos Alcaraz triumphs in the latest chapter of his compelling rivalry with Jannik Sinner, earning a four-set victory to regain the US Open title.

items.title: Man Utd keeper Onana agrees Trabzonspor loan
items.summary: Manchester United goalkeeper Andre Onana agrees a loan move to Trabzonspor, with Turkey's transfer window open until Friday.

items.title: Humphries beats Rock to retain Czech Open title
items.summary: World number one Luke Humphries beats Josh Rock 8-5 in the final of the Czech Open - defending the title he won a year ago.

items.title: Liverpool rule out Guehi move in January - Monday's gossip
items.summary: England defender Marc Guehi will not be joining Liverpool from Crystal Palace in January, Manchester United goalkeeper Andre Onana will double his wages on loan at Trabzonspor, Dele Alli is interesting three English clubs, plus more.

items.title: Tuchel wants England to consider long throws
items.summary: England boss Thomas Tuchel wants his team to use long throw-ins and play long balls at next summer's World Cup.

items.title: Toone scores in dominant Man Utd win
items.summary: Ella Toone and Melvine Malard were among the Manchester United scorers in a dominant display against Leicester City at Leigh Sports Village.

items.title: 'Title fight refuses to get nasty, even when McLaren create own controversy'

items.title: Ireland 'didn't get into their flow' in Black Ferns loss
items.summary: Ireland centre Aoife Dalton says her side failed to "capitalise" on opportunities against New Zealand as they suffered a 40-0 defeat against the reigning world champions in Brighton.

items.title: Bethell and Archer star as England beat South Africa by record margin

items.title: McIlroy wins Irish Open in dramatic play-off
items.summary: Rory McIlroy holds his nerve to win the Irish Open in a dramatic play-off and claim his first victory since completing the career Grand Slam at the Masters in April.

items.title: Putin says organ transplants could grant immortality. Not quite.
items.summary: This week Iâ€™m writing from Manchester, where Iâ€™ve been attending a conference on aging. Wednesday was full of talks and presentations by scientists who are trying to understand the nitty-gritty of agingâ€”all the way down to the molecular level. Once we can understand the complex biology of aging, weâ€¦
items.body: This week Iâ€™m writing from Manchester, where Iâ€™ve been attending  a conference on aging . Wednesday was full of talks and presentations by scientists who are trying to understand the nitty-gritty of agingâ€”all the way down to the molecular level. Once we can understand the complex biology of aging, we should be able to slow or prevent the onset of age-related diseases, they hope. Then my editor forwarded me a video of the leaders of Russia and China talking about immortality. â€œThese days at 70 years old you are still a child,â€ Chinaâ€™s Xi Jinping, 72, was translated as saying, according to footage livestreamed by CCTV to  multiple   media outlets. â€œWith the developments of biotechnology, human organs can be continuously transplanted, and people can live younger and younger, and even achieve immortality,â€ Russiaâ€™s Vladimir Putin, also 72, is reported to have replied. SERGEI BOBYLEV, SPUTNIK, KREMLIN POOL PHOTO VIA AP Thereâ€™s a striking contrast between that radical vision and the incremental longevity science presented at the meeting. Repeated rounds of organ transplantation surgery arenâ€™t likely to help anyone radically extend their lifespan anytime soon. First, back â€¦

Banks are increasingly employing agentic AI to optimize processes, navigate complex systems, and sift through vast quantities of unstructured data to make decisions and take actionsâ€”with or without huâ€¦
items.body: Agentic AI is coming of age. And with it comes new opportunities in the financial services sector. Banks are increasingly employing agentic AI to optimize processes, navigate complex systems, and sift through vast quantities of unstructured data to make decisions and take actionsâ€”with or without human involvement. â€œWith the maturing of agentic AI, it is becoming a lot more technologically possible for large-scale process automation that was not possible with rules-based approaches like robotic process automation before,â€ says Sameer Gupta, Americas financial services AI leader at EY. â€œThat moves the needle in terms of cost, efficiency, and customer experience impact.â€ From responding to customer services requests, to automating loan approvals, adjusting bill payments to align with regular paychecks, or extracting key terms and conditions from financial agreements, agentic AI has the potential to transform the customer experienceâ€”and how financial institutions operate too. DOWNLOAD THE REPORT Adapting to new and emerging technologies like agentic AI is essential for an organizationâ€™s survival, says Murli Buluswar, head of US personal banking analytics at Citi. â€œA companyâ€™s ability â€¦

Synthesiaâ€™s AI clones are more expressive than ever. Soon theyâ€™ll be able to talk back. â€”Rhiannon Williams Earlier this summer, I visited the AI company Synthesia to give it what it needed to create a hyperrealistic AI-generated avatar of me. The companyâ€™s avatars are a decent barometer of just how dizzying progress has been in AI over the past few years, so I was curious just how accurately its latest AI model, introduced last month, could replicate me. I found my avatar as unnerving as it is technically impressive. Itâ€™s slick enough to pass as a high-definition recording of a chirpy corporate speech, and if you didnâ€™t know me, youâ€™d probably think thatâ€™s exactly what it was.  My avatar shows how itâ€™s becoming ever-harder to distinguish the artificial from the real. And before long, these avatars will even be able to talk back to us. But how much better can they get? And what might interacting with AI clones do to us? Read the full story . How Trump is helping China extend its massive lead in clean energy  On a spring dayâ€¦

items.title: Transforming CX with embedded real-time analytics
items.summary: During Black Friday in 2024, Stripe processed more than $31 billion in transactions, with processing rates peaking at 137,000 transactions per minute, the highest in the companyâ€™s history. The financial-services firm had to analyze every transaction in real time to prevent nearly 21 million fraud aâ€¦
items.body: During Black Friday in 2024, Stripe processed more than $31 billion in transactions, with processing rates peaking at 137,000 transactions per minute, the highest in the companyâ€™s history. The financial-services firm had to analyze every transaction in real time to prevent nearly 21 million fraud attempts that could have siphoned more than $910 million from its merchant customers.  Yet, fraud protection is only one reason that Stripe embraced real-time data analytics. Evaluating trends in massive data flows is essential for the companyâ€™s services, such as allowing businesses to bill based on usage and monitor orders and inventory. In fact, many of Stripeâ€™s services would not be possible without real-time analytics, says Avinash Bhat, head of data infrastructure at Stripe. â€œWe have certain products that require real-time analytics, like usage-based billing and fraud detection,â€ he says. â€œWithout our real-time analytics, we would not have a few of our products and thatâ€™s why itâ€™s super important.â€  DOWNLOAD THE REPORT Stripe is not alone. In todayâ€™s digital world, data analysis is increasingly delivered directly to business customers and individual users, allowing reaâ€¦

items.title: 'He fixes what needs fixing' - why Raducanu turned to Nadal's ex-coach
items.summary: Emma Raducanu recently appointed another full-time coach in Spaniard Francisco Roig - BBC Sport speaks to those who know him best.

items.title: 'He has made young players dream' - the making of Liverpool icon Salah
items.summary: BBC Sport visits Egypt to discover what Mohamed Salah means to the people of the football-mad country, and how a small boy from humble beginnings became a national icon.

items.title: Becky Zerlentes - the first female boxer to die in fight in US
items.summary: The story of Becky Zerlentes - the first female boxer to die in a sanctioned fight in the United States.

items.title: How Hampton overcame odds to become England's number one
items.summary: Hannah Hampton on overcoming a serious eye condition to rise to become England's number one goalkeeper at Euro 2025.

items.title: Why 'best-dressed officials' are missing from Wimbledon
items.summary: Wimbledon is without line judges for the first time - will 'sport's best dressed officials' be missed?
